title: Understanding the Factors of Mental Health
text:
Let’s get started.



# For data manipulation and tidying
library(dplyr)
library(lubridate)
library(tidyr)

# For mapping
library(ggmap)
library(mapproj)

# For data visualizations
library(ggplot2)

# For modeling and machine learning
library(caret)




All of the data can be downloaded from Kaggle.

results <- read.csv(file = "Mental-Health-Dataset.csv")

Ok, let’s take a look at each of these data files.






Rows: 292,364
Columns: 17
$ Timestamp               <chr> "2014-08-27 11:29:31", "2014-08-27 11:31:50", …
$ Gender                  <chr> "Female", "Female", "Female", "Female", "Femal…
$ Country                 <chr> "United States", "United States", "United Stat…
$ Occupation              <chr> "Corporate", "Corporate", "Corporate", "Corpor…
$ self_employed           <chr> "", "", "", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ family_history          <chr> "No", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "No", "Yes",…
$ treatment               <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ Days_Indoors            <chr> "1-14 days", "1-14 days", "1-14 days", "1-14 d…
$ Growing_Stress          <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ Changes_Habits          <chr> "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ Mental_Health_History   <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ Mood_Swings             <chr> "Medium", "Medium", "Medium", "Medium", "Mediu…
$ Coping_Struggles        <chr> "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ Work_Interest           <chr> "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ Social_Weakness         <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ mental_health_interview <chr> "No", "No", "No", "Maybe", "No", "Maybe", "No"…
$ care_options            <chr> "Not sure", "No", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Not su…


There are 17 variables in the data results data frame:

Timestamp: Time and date of survey.
Gender: Gender of the respondent.
Country: The country where the respondent lives.
Occupation: Occupation or profession of the respondent.
self_employed: Is the respondent self-employed or not?
family_history: Is there a history of mental health disorders in the respondent’s family?
treatment: Has the respondent ever received treatment or therapy for mental health problems?
Days_Indoors: Estimated number of days a week the respondent spends indoors.
Growing_Stress: The current level of stress the respondent feels.
Changes_habits: Has the respondent experienced any changes in sleeping habits or patterns?
Mental_Health_History: Does the respondent have a previous history of mental health disorders?
Mood_Swings: Does the respondent experience sudden mood swings?
Coping_Struggles: Does the respondent have difficulty coping with pressure or stress?
Work_Interest: The respondent’s level of interest and motivation in their work.
Social_Weakness: Does the respondent find difficulty to interact socially or maintain relationships?
mental_health_interview: Is the respondent willing to be interviewed about their mental health?
care_options: Is the respondent aware of or using mental health care options?

title: Understanding the Factors of Mental Health
text:
# For data manipulation and tidying
library(dplyr)
library(lubridate)
library(tidyr)

# For mapping
library(ggmap)
library(mapproj)

# For data visualizations
library(ggplot2)

# For modeling and machine learning
library(caret)

title: Understanding the Factors of Mental Health
text:
All of the data can be downloaded from Kaggle.

results <- read.csv(file = "Mental-Health-Dataset.csv")

Ok, let’s take a look at each of these data files.






Rows: 292,364
Columns: 17
$ Timestamp               <chr> "2014-08-27 11:29:31", "2014-08-27 11:31:50", …
$ Gender                  <chr> "Female", "Female", "Female", "Female", "Femal…
$ Country                 <chr> "United States", "United States", "United Stat…
$ Occupation              <chr> "Corporate", "Corporate", "Corporate", "Corpor…
$ self_employed           <chr> "", "", "", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ family_history          <chr> "No", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "No", "Yes",…
$ treatment               <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ Days_Indoors            <chr> "1-14 days", "1-14 days", "1-14 days", "1-14 d…
$ Growing_Stress          <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ Changes_Habits          <chr> "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ Mental_Health_History   <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ Mood_Swings             <chr> "Medium", "Medium", "Medium", "Medium", "Mediu…
$ Coping_Struggles        <chr> "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ Work_Interest           <chr> "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No", "No"…
$ Social_Weakness         <chr> "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes…
$ mental_health_interview <chr> "No", "No", "No", "Maybe", "No", "Maybe", "No"…
$ care_options            <chr> "Not sure", "No", "Yes", "Yes", "Yes", "Not su…


There are 17 variables in the data results data frame:

Timestamp: Time and date of survey.
Gender: Gender of the respondent.
Country: The country where the respondent lives.
Occupation: Occupation or profession of the respondent.
self_employed: Is the respondent self-employed or not?
family_history: Is there a history of mental health disorders in the respondent’s family?
treatment: Has the respondent ever received treatment or therapy for mental health problems?
Days_Indoors: Estimated number of days a week the respondent spends indoors.
Growing_Stress: The current level of stress the respondent feels.
Changes_habits: Has the respondent experienced any changes in sleeping habits or patterns?
Mental_Health_History: Does the respondent have a previous history of mental health disorders?
Mood_Swings: Does the respondent experience sudden mood swings?
Coping_Struggles: Does the respondent have difficulty coping with pressure or stress?
Work_Interest: The respondent’s level of interest and motivation in their work.
Social_Weakness: Does the respondent find difficulty to interact socially or maintain relationships?
mental_health_interview: Is the respondent willing to be interviewed about their mental health?
care_options: Is the respondent aware of or using mental health care options?

title: Understanding the Factors of Mental Health
text:
Demographics Data Visualization
Let’s explore a little at the different demographics such as Gender and Occupation that the data set has.


# A tibble: 2 × 2
# Groups:   Gender [2]
  Gender      n
  <chr>   <int>
1 Female  52514
2 Male   239850


There are 2 genders in this data set with male being the majority number.


# A tibble: 5 × 2
# Groups:   Occupation [5]
  Occupation     n
  <chr>      <int>
1 Business   50149
2 Corporate  61229
3 Housewife  66351
4 Others     52841
5 Student    61794


There are 5 different occupations.


# A tibble: 35 × 2
# Groups:   Country [35]
   Country                    n
   <chr>                  <int>
 1 Australia               6026
 2 Belgium                  824
 3 Bosnia and Herzegovina   390
 4 Brazil                  2340
 5 Canada                 18726
 6 Colombia                 390
 7 Costa Rica               390
 8 Croatia                  390
 9 Czech Republic           390
10 Denmark                  780
# ℹ 25 more rows


There are 35 countries.
Let’s make a graph that has gender and occupation in it while facet wrapped by countries.





Figure 1: 35 side-by-side graphs, one for each country. Each has a seperate line based off of gender and it is grouped by occupation, showing activity by hour of the day when the data was collected.




Since we did a count of demographics, let’s see how they interact with the different factors of mental health.

title: Understanding the Factors of Mental Health
text:
Gender
Gender is a well known demographic that has different disparities when it comes to mental health. Usually, women are more at risk for mood disorder and symptoms and anxiety disorders and symptoms. However, since there is a lot more men in that data set compare to women, the data might tell us something else. So why don’t we take a look at how gender plays a role in some of the factors of mental health.
For this, let’s look at Growing_Stress, Mood_Swings, Treatment, Coping_Struggles, Mental_Health_History, and Family_History.

History
Let’s start with how participants who have a history with mental health based on gender.





Figure 2: A bar graph showing the number of people who have history with mental health based on gender.




As predicted, there is more men then women who have a history with mental health. But what about family history?





Figure 3: A bar graph showing the number of people whose families have a history of mental health based on gender.




How interesting that family_history doesn’t have a maybe column like the previous bar graph. Just like the previous graph, it is overwhelmingly men then women.


Symptoms
In this section, let’s look at how gender can play into effect at different mental health symptoms that can pre-determine or factor into mental health.





Figure 4: A bar graph showing the number of people who stress has been increasing based off of gender.




Well that’s interesting. Even though there is still an overwhelmingly huge response from men, a good portion of women said yes to being stress compared to the no and maybe responses. Meanwhile for men, there is only a slightly higher stress levels compared to the no category while it’s mostly a maybe for men.





Figure 5: A bar graph showing the number of people who experienced mood swings based off of gender.




The responses for this graph is slightly similar to the increase in stress graph. While men are ranked lower in the high category for mood swings, it seems like their highest category is medium mood swings. Meanwhile, women experience high mood swings and about the same amount of mood swings in the other two categories.


Treatment and Coping
In this section, let’s look at how gender can play into effect in how people receive treatment or have difficulty in coping with pressure or stress.





Figure 6: A bar graph showing how different genders interact coping with pressure and stress.




It seems like while men are less likely to struggle coping with pressure and stress, women are more likely to struggle.





Figure 7: A bar graph showing if different genders recieve treatment.




That’s a huge disparity. It seems like more women are receiving treatment or therapy for their mental health problems compared to men who mainly don’t receive anything for their mental health problems.

title: Understanding the Factors of Mental Health
text:
Occupation
Occupation is another well known demographic that has different disparities when it comes to mental health. Usually, those who are unemployed or students has more mental health problems due to socioeconomic reasons.
For this, let’s look at Growing_Stress, Work_Interest, Coping_Struggles, Changes_Habits, Social_Weakness, and Mental_Health_History.

Stress and Work Interest
In this section let’s see how stress can play into work interest for different occupations. From there, let’s see if there have been any coping difficulties to manage the pressure and stress.





Figure 8: Five side-by-side graphs, one for each occupation. Each has a seperate line based off of interest and motivation in work and it is grouped by and colored by stress levels each participant is feeling.




For a majority of these occupations, it seems like when there is a small amount of stress and pressure put upon them, the more interested and motivated they are in their work.
So how does this play into how they cope with that stress based on occupation?





Figure 9: Five side-by-side graphs, one for each occupation. Each has a seperate line based off of difficulty in how the participant copes with stress and it is grouped by and colored by stress levels each participant is feeling.




It seems that those with high levels of stress are also having difficulty managing stress, which is affecting their mental health.


Changes
I want to see if depending on the occupation and stress, if there have been any changes in their sleeping habits or patters. Additionally, does the type of occupation and stress affect relationships?
Let’s start off by looking into how sleep patterns and habits are affected by types of occupation and stress.





Figure 10: Five side-by-side graphs, one for each occupation. Each has a seperate line based off changes in sleep patterns and habits and it is grouped by and colored by stress levels each participant is feeling.




Seems like most changes of sleep patterns and habits correlate with a high level of stress.
Let’s now look into how it may have been difficult to interact socially or maintain relationships based on stress and occupation.





Figure 11: Five side-by-side graphs, one for each occupation. Each has a seperate line based off difficulty interacting and maintaining relationships. It is grouped by and colored by stress levels each participant is feeling.




It seems to be all over the place depending on the occupation. Looks like that the majority have said it was difficult to maintain a relationship or interact socially depending on the occupation and current levels of stress.


Mental Health
Finally, in this section let’s look at how mental health is affected by occupations.





Figure 12: Three side-by-side bars, one for each response for participants who indicated that have had history of mental health disorders. It is filled by different indications of stress levels. Pink is maybe, light blue is no, and purple is yes.




It looks like it also depends on the occupation participants have. It is all over the place for maybe having mental health disorder and seems like those who indicated that they may have some levels of stress may also have some mental health disorder. There seems that a participant has either indicated no or a maybe to having stress with no mental heath disorders.There is a low indication and confirmation from participants that they have some form of mental health disorder. From here they mainly either indicated yes or a maybe for increase in stress.

title: About Me
text:
Hi, I’m Sydney Traugott!
This website is a product of my statistics class called, Data Management and Visualization.
I’m currently a psychology major at Appalachian State University. Besides being a senior at AppState, I’m currently a research assistant and in the Honor’s College. Currently I’m aiming to get a PsyD in Clinical Psychology.





If you have any questions, contact me at: traugottsl@appstate.edu.

title: STT 2860 Intro to Data Management and Visual

title: Combining Datasets
text:
Problem 1
Take a look at the three data frames - happy, happy_join_one, and happy_full

glimpse(happy)

Rows: 5
Columns: 4
$ country_name   <chr> "Iraq", "Comoros", "Panama", "Maldives", "Spain"
$ ladder_score   <dbl> 4.854, 4.289, 6.180, 5.198, 6.491
$ gdp            <dbl> 9.240, 8.031, 10.350, 9.826, 10.571
$ social_support <dbl> 0.746, 0.626, 0.896, 0.913, 0.932

glimpse(happy_join_one)

Rows: 5
Columns: 2
$ country_name            <chr> "Iraq", "Comoros", "Panama", "Maldives", "Spai…
$ healthy_life_expectancy <dbl> 60.583, 57.349, 69.652, 70.600, 74.700

glimpse(happy_full)

Rows: 149
Columns: 20

title: Combining Datasets
text:
Problem 2
Combine happy and happy_join_one by row

bind_rows(happy, happy_join_one)

# A tibble: 10 × 5
   country_name ladder_score   gdp social_support healthy_life_expectancy
   <chr>               <dbl> <dbl>          <dbl>                   <dbl>

title: Combining Datasets
text:
Problem 3
Combine happy and happy_join_one by column.

nrow(happy) == nrow(happy_join_one)

[1] TRUE

bind_cols(happy, happy_join_one)

New names:
• `country_name` -> `country_name...1`
• `country_name` -> `country_name...5`


# A tibble: 5 × 6
  country_name...1 ladder_score   gdp social_support country_name...5
  <chr>                   <dbl> <dbl>          <dbl> <chr>           
1 Iraq                     4.85  9.24          0.746 Iraq            
2 Comoros                  4.29  8.03          0.626 Comoros         
3 Panama                   6.18 10.4           0.896 Panama          
4 Maldives                 5.20  9.83          0.913 Maldives        
5 Spain                    6.49 10.6           0.932 Spain           
# ℹ 1 more variable: healthy_life_expectancy <dbl>

title: Combining Datasets
text:
Problem 4
Which join_* function is a better alternative to the previous solution?

happy %>%
  inner_join(happy_join_one)

Joining with `by = join_by(country_name)`

  country_name ladder_score   gdp social_support healthy_life_expectancy
